The Global Legal Practice Think Tank
Matterhorn Law is a research organization- a global leagl practice think tank - dedicated to promoting the efficient practice of Law.

Its scholars and researchers maintain this web based legal practice resource platform and understake research on significant legal practice issues with global application. As a result of its activities, Matterhorn Law provides practical advice on legal practice management for both in-house lega departments and law firms.

The goal of Matterhorn Law is to promote efficieny in legal practice management. Such managemnet is often problematic. The issue that may arise in connection with the management of a legal practice are potentially infinite. 


The first research initiative for the scholars and researchers at Matterhorn Law is in respect of the appropriate parameters for the organization of an in-house legal department. The second initiative is in respect of the determination of teh appropriate parameters for a law firm to take a decision to open an office outside of its home jurisdiction.
The issues with respect to an in-house legal department may include the following:
The issues with respect to a law firm with global aspirations may include the following:
All contributors from the Matterhorn Law community of users in respect of these initiatives are welcome.

● How should an in-house legal department be organized for a company with global reach? 

● Should a legal department with global reach be centralized or decentralized? 

● What practice areas should be developed in-house? 

● What matters can be handled in-house? 

● If not, how should a law firm be chosen? For example, with respect to dispute resolution, are certain law firms better at certain types of disputes, e.g., construction disputes. 

● Should a law firm panel be organized and maintained? 

● What fee arrangements are appropriate for law firms? Should a success fee be considered in whole or in part? 

● How should a dispute with respect to the fees of a law firm be resolved?

● When should a law firm contemplate the opening of an office outside of its home jurisdiction? 

● The international office should develop which practice areas? 

● The international office should develop expertise in respect of which industry sectors?

Joseph has been engaged in the practice of law for approximately 37 years. 

He has lived and practiced in New York(Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison), Peurto Rico(McConnell valdes), London(FreshFields Bruckhaus Deringer), Paris (Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison and subsequently FreshFields Bruckhaus Deringer), Dubai (FreshFields Bruckhaus Deringer), Abu Dhabi (FreshFields Bruckhaus Deringer), Qatar (Newton Legal), Behrain (FreshFields Bruckhaus Deringer and subsequently Newton Legal), , South Korea (Lee & Ko), Taiwan (Formosa Transational) and Tokyo(Matsuo & Kosugi). 

Joseph was a member of the Freshfields’ Project Finance and International Arbitration Groups for 20 years. 

He is the author of the book “Understanding and Negotiating EPC and Turnkey Contracts” published by Sweet & Maxwell. 

He frequently sits as arbitrator. Joseph was until recently a member of the LCIA Court as the special delegate for the DIFC-LCIA Arbitration Centre. He was the first Registrar of the DIFC-LCIA Arbitration Centre. 

Since leaving Freshfields, Joseph has founded and developed one of the most successful regional law firms in the Middle East: Newton Legal. 

In addition, Joseph frequently provides advice regarding the management of global law firms and the organization (and reorganization) of in-house legal departments.
\u25CF JD/MBA: Boston College \n\u25CF Masters in Business and Tax Law: University of Paris I(Pantheon-Sorbonne)

● McConnell Valdes (1980 to 1983) 
● Law Offices of S.G. Archibald (1983 to 1989 and including three secondments referred to below) 
● Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison (1989-1992) 
● Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer: (1992-2012) – MENA Regional Managing Partner 
● Newton Legal (2012 to present) 
● Newton Consult (2016 to present)
